titleStmt.title: Digital edition of MonſieurMonsieur Acarete du Biscay's Journey from Buenos Ayres to Peru
titleStmt.author: Alice Bi, Julieta Goldsmidt, Nery González, Carlos Nusch

bibl.author: Acarete Du Biscay
bibl.title: Monſieur Acarete du Biscay's Journey from Buenos Ayres to Peru

body.head: MonſieurMonsieur Acarete du Biscay's Journey from Buenos Ayres to Peru
body.p:
I Left Buenos AyresBuenos Aires, and took the Road
to CordouaCórdoba, leaving Santa Fe on my
right hand, of which place take this ac
count, 'tisit's a SpaniſhSpanish Settlement dependant
upon Buenos AyresBuenos Aires, the Commander is
no more than a Lieutenant, and does no
thing but by order from the Governor
of Buenos AyresBuenos Aires. 'Tisit's a little place con
taining 25 HoufesHouses, without any Walls,
Fortifications, or GarriſonGarrison, diſtantdistant 80 Leagues
from Buenos AyresBuenos Aires Northward,
Situate upon the River de la Plata, large
VeſſelsVessels might come up to it, were it not
for a great bank that obstructs the pas
sage a little above Buenos AyresBuenos Aires.
NevertheleſsNeverthelerss 'tisit's a very advantageous PoſtPost,
because 'tisit's the only passage from Peru,
Chili and TucumanTucumán to Paraguay, and in a
manner the Magazine of the Commodi
ties drawn from thence, particularly that
Herb already ſpokenspoken of, which they
cannot be without in thoſethose Provinces.
The Soil is as good and Fertile here as
at Buenos AyresBuenos Aires; and the Town having
nothing remarkably different from what
has been observ'dobserved of Buenos AyresBuenos Aires, I
leave it, and proceed upon my Jour
ney. 'Tisit's counted 140 Leagues from
Buenos AyresBuenos Aires to CordouaCórdoba, and becauſebecause
ſomesome parts of the Road are uninhabited
for a long way together; I ſurnishedsurnished my ſelfself at
my departure with what I
was inform'dinformed I fhouldshould ftandstand in need
of; ſoso I ſetset out having a Savage for my
Guide, with Three HorſesHorses and Three Mules
, ſomesome to carry my Baggage, and
the reftrest to change upon the way when
that I rid upon was tired.
From Buenos AyresBuenos Aires, to the River Lu
canLuján, and even as far as the River Recife,
30 Leagues, I pass’d by several Habita
tions and Farms cultivated by the Spani
ards, but beyond Recife to the River
SalladilloSaladillo, I fawsaw none. Let it be obſer
vedobserved by the way, that theſethese Rivers as well
as all the reſtchoice in the Provinces of Buenos
AyresBuenos Aires, Paraguay and TucumanTucumán, that fall
into the River de la Plata are fordable
on horfehorse-back; but when the Rains or
any
other accident ſwellsswells them, a
Traveller muſtmust either ſwimswim over, or elſeelse get
upon a bundle in the nature of a raft,
which a Savage hawls over to the other
ſideside. I could not Swim, and ſoso was
forc'dforced to make uſeuse of this expedient
twice or thrice when I could not find a
Ford. The way was this, my
kill'dkilled a Wild Bull, flead the Hide off,
ſtuffedstuffed it with ſtrawstraw, and ty'dtied it up in
a great bundle with thongs of the ſamesame
Hide, upon which I plac'dplaced my ſelfself with
my Baggage; he ſwamswam over hawling me
after him by a Cord ty'dtied to the bundle,
and then he repaſs'drepulsed and ſwamswam my HorſesHorses
and Mules over to me.

All the Country between the River
Recife and SalladilloSaladillo, tho' uninhabited,
abounds in Cattle and all ſorts of Fruit
trees, except Walnut and Chesnut-trees;
there are whole Woods of Nectarine-
Trees, Three or Four Leagues in compaſscompass,
that bear excellent Fruit, which they
not only eat raw, but bake them, or dry
them in the Sun, to keep, as we in France
do Prunes: They ſeldom uſeseldom use any other
than the Wood of this Tree for common
firing at Buenos AyresBuenos Aires, and thereabouts.
The Savages that dwell in theſethese Parts are
diſtinguiſh'ddistinguished into two sorts, those that voluntarilyſubmitSubmit to the Spaniardsare call’d PanpiſtasPanpistas, the reſtrest Serranos, both cloathed with Skins, but the laſt ſetlast set up on the PanpiſtasPanpistas as their mortal Enemies wherever they meet with them. All Fight on Horſe-back, either with Lances pointed with Iron or Bones ſharpen'dsharpened, or else with Bows and Arrows, they wear Bulls-hides faſhion'dfashioned like a Doublet without ſleevessleeves, to defend their Bodies. Their Chiefs that command over them in War and Peace, are call’d Couracas. When they take any one of their Enemies, alive or dead, they meet all together, and after they have reproach'dreproached him, that either he or his Relations were the death of their Kindred or Friends, they cut and tear him into pieces, which they roaſtroast a little and eat, making a drinking Bowl of his Scull. They feed moſtlymostly upon flesh either raw or dreſs'ddressed, and particularly Colts fleſhflesh, which they like! better than Veal. They catch abundance of FiſhFish likewiſelikewise in their Rivers, They have no ſettledsettled places of aboad, but ramble up and down, ſeveralseveral Families together, and live in Tents.

I could not inform my ſelfself exactly what Religion they were of, but I was told that they look'dlooked upon the Sun and Moon as Deities and as I travell'dtravelled along, I ſawsaw a Savage upon his knees with his Face to the Sun, who cry'dcried out and made ſtrangestrange geſturesgestures with his Hands and Arms. I learn'dlearned from the Savage that accompany'daccompanied me, that he was one of thoſethose they call'd Papas, who in the Morning kneel towards the Sun, and at Night towards the Moon, to ſupplicatesupplicate those fancy'dfancied Divinities to be propitious to them, to give them fair Weather, and Victory over their Foes.

They make no great Ceremony in their Marriages ; but when a Relation dies, after they have rubb’d his body with a certain Earth that conſumesconsumes all but the Bones, they preserve them, and carry as many of them as they can conveniently about with them in a ſortsort of CheſtsChests, and this they do in token of their affection to their Kindred; indeed they are not wanting in good Offices to them during their Lives, nor in their SickneſsSickness and Death.

Along the River SalladilloSaladillo, I took notice of a great many ParratsParrots, or Papagays, as the Spaniards call them, and certain Birds, call’dcalled Guacamayos, which are of divers Colours, and twice or thrice as big as a ParratsParrots. The River it ſelfself is full of the FiſhFish, call'dcalled Dorado, which is very good to eat. There is alſoalso a Creature in it, whether 'tisit's Meat or PoyſonPoison no body knows, it has Four Feet and a long Tail like a Lizard.

From SalladilloSaladillo quite to CordouaCórdoba, you go along a very fine River, that abounds with FiſhFish, which is neither wide nor deep, for it may be forded over. On the Bank of it you meet with little Plantations every Three or Four Leagues; which are like Country HouſesHouses inhabited by Spaniards, Portuguese, and the Natives, who have all the neceſſarynecessary accomodations of Life they can wiſhwish, and are very Civil and Charitable to Strangers; their principal Wealth is in HorſesHorses and Mules, in which they Trade with the Inhabitants of Peru.

CordouaCórdoba is a Town Situate in a pleaſantpleasant and fruitful Plain upon the ſideside of a River, bigger and broader than that I have juſtjust ſpokenspoken of: 'Tisit's compos’dcomposed of about 400 Houses, Built like thoſethose of Buenos AyresBuenos Aires. It has neither Ditches, nor Walls, nor Fort for its defence; He that Commands it is Governor of all the Provinces of TucumanTucumán, and tho’ it be the place of his ordinary Residence, yet he is wont now and then, as he ſeessees occaſionoccasion, to go and paſspass ſomesome time at de St. Jago l’EſtroSantiago del Estero, at St. Miguel de TucumanTucumán, (which is the Capital City of the Province) at Salta and at XuxuiJujuy. In each of theſethese Villages there is a Lieutenant, who has under him an Alcalde and ſomesome Officers for the AdminiſtrationAdministration of JuſticeJustice. The BiſhopBishop of TucumanTucumán likewiſelikewise uſuallyusually reſidesresides at CordouaCórdoba, where the Cathedral is the only PariſhParish Church of the whole Town, but there are divers Convents of Monks, namely of Dominicans, Recollects, and those of the Order de la Mercy: and one of Nunns. The Jesuits have a College there, and their Chappelchapel is the fineſtfinest and richeſtrichest of all.

The Inhabitants are Rich in Gold and Silver, which they get by the Trade they have for Mules, with which they furniſhfurnish Peru and other Parts; which is ſoso conſiderableconsiderable, that they ſellsell about 28 or 30000 of 'em every Year, which they breed up in their Farms. They usually keep 'em till they are about Two Years old, then expose 'em to Sale, and have about Six Patagons a piece for 'em. The Merchants that come to buy 'em, carry 'em to St. JagoSantiago, to Salta and XuxuiJujuy, where they leave 'em for Three Years, till they are well grown and become ſtrongstrong, and afterwards bring 'em to Peru, where they preſentlypresently have Vent for 'em, becauſebecause there as well as in the reſtrest of the Western part of America, the greateſtgreatest part of their Carriage is upon Mules. The People of CordouaCórdoba alſoalso drive a Trade in Cows, which they have from the CountreyCountry of Buenos AyresBuenos Aires, and carry to Peru, where without this way of SubſiſtanceSubsistance 'tis certain they would have much ado to live. This kind of Trafficktraffic makes this Town the moſtmost conſiderableconsiderable in the Province of TucumanTucumán, as well for its Riches and Commodities, as for the Number of its Inhabitants, which are counted to be at leaſt 5 or 600 Families, beſidesbesides Slaves who are three times the number. But the generality of 'em of all degrees have no other Arms but a Sword and Poignard, and are very indifferent Souldiers, the Air of the Country, and the Plenty they enjoy, rendring them Lazy and Cowardly. ___________________________________
